metadata.case_name: M. L. Sethi v. P. Kapur

facts.text: On December 10, 1958, the appellant lodged a report with the Inspector-General of Police, Chandigarh against P. Kapur (respondent) and his mother-in-law charging them with commission of offences punishable under sections 420, 109, 114 and 120-B, I.P.C. based on allegation that they cheated appellant and his wife of Rs. 20,000/- by false representations in sale-deed of land already acquired by Government.
Offence registered as cognizable and investigation started by police.

On April 11, 1959, the respondent filed a complaint in the Court of Judicial Magistrate, 1st Class, Chandigarh, against the appellant for commission of offences under sections 204, 211 and 385 I.P.C., alleging that land was sold as favour, appellant knew of acquisition, demanded Rs.13,000/- threatening criminal proceedings, lodged false FIR to induce payment, secreted five documents.
On the same day April 11, 1959, Magistrate took cognizance under s.190 CrPC and recorded statement under s.200 CrPC.
Respondent arrested on July 18, 1959 in connection with appellant's FIR; challan presented by police on July 25, 1959.
Both proceedings (police case on FIR and respondent's complaint) transferred to Court of Additional District Magistrate, Saharanpur.
Case against respondent and mother-in-law based on FIR ended in order of discharge by High Court of Allahabad on December 10, 1962, quashing charges.
Appellant filed application on May 6, 1963 before Addl. DM Saharanpur to dismiss complaint, contending no offence disclosed, barred by s.195 CrPC, facts inter-mixed, discharge under s.253 CrPC.
Addl. DM by order dated August 6, 1963 dismissed appellant's application.
Appellant filed another application dated August 12, 1963 praying no cognizance of complaint due to s.195(1)(b) CrPC for s.211 IPC.
Addl. DM by order dated October 5, 1963 rejected contention that s.195 CrPC barred complaint as no proceedings pending in court when filed.
Sessions Judge of Saharanpur upheld the two orders of Addl. DM.
High Court at Allahabad dismissed appellant's revision on January 13, 1965.
High Court granted certificate for appeal to Supreme Court.

legal_issues.text: Whether cognizance of the complaint including offence under s.211 IPC filed on April 11, 1959 was barred by s.195(1)(b) CrPC, as at that time only police investigation was ongoing on appellant's FIR of Dec 10, 1958, and no proceeding in any court existed.
Whether lodging FIR of cognizable offence institutes 'proceeding in any court' or 'charges' person for purpose of s.211 IPC and attracts s.195 CrPC.

petitioner_arguments.text: Making report of cognizable offence to police institutes criminal proceeding and charges person, so s.195 CrPC attracted for complaint under s.211 IPC.
petitioner_arguments.legal_basis: s.211 IPC; s.195 CrPC; Karim Buksh v. Queen-Empress (Full Bench Calcutta); Albert v. State of Kerala (Full Bench Kerala)

petitioner_arguments.text: No offence under s.211 IPC disclosed (given up in SC); trial barred by want of sanction u/s 195 CrPC; facts inter-mixed so no separate trial for other offences.
Bar u/s 195(1)(b) applies even if proceeding in contemplation, as expression 'in relation to' widens scope.
petitioner_arguments.legal_basis: s.195(1)(b) CrPC; various High Court cases like Re Vasudeo Ramchandra Joshi, Ghulam Rasul v. Emperor

respondent_arguments.text: No proceedings pending in any court when complaint filed on Apr 11, 1959, only police investigation, so s.195 CrPC inapplicable.
Complaint specifically includes charge under s.211 IPC.

court_reasoning.text: Cognizance u/s 190 CrPC subject to limitation u/s 195; at time of cognizance Apr 11, 1959, no proceeding in any court existed, only police investigation which is not 'proceeding in any court'; bar u/s 195(1)(b) requires existing or concluded court proceeding.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Police investigation not proceeding in court; proceeding in contemplation not sufficient for bar.

court_reasoning.text: s.195(1)(b) bars cognizance only if offence u/s 211 alleged committed in or relation to proceeding in any court; ingredients: offence u/s 211, proceeding in court, offence in/relation to it; here first ingredient yes, but no court proceeding on date of cognizance.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Point of time for judging cognizance is when taken u/s 190.

court_reasoning.text: Distinguished cited cases as in those, court proceeding existed or concluded by time of cognizance; rejected view that contemplated proceeding attracts bar.
court_reasoning.key_observation: No uncertainty from future decisions; scheme of CrPC ss.154-173 shows Magistrate intervenes only post s.173 report.

court_reasoning.text: s.195 limits court power to take cognizance, does not make act non-offence; private complaint permissible before any court proceeding.

holdings.text: Judicial Magistrate competent to take cognizance of complaint on Apr 11, 1959 as no proceeding in any court then; s.195(1)(b) CrPC not attracted; trial for ss.204,211,385 IPC can proceed.

precedents_cited.relevance: Petitioner relied for FIR instituting proceeding; court did not decide.
Petitioner relied for FIR instituting proceeding; court did not decide.
Court proceeding pending when complaint filed.
FIR institutes criminal proceeding for s.211 but not court proceeding.
No bar to private complaint during police enquiry.
Court proceedings pending without final order.

precedents_cited.case_name: H. N. Rishbud v. State of Delhi
precedents_cited.relevance: Scheme of police investigation under CrPC.

statutes_cited.name: Indian Penal Code, 1860
statutes_cited.relevance: Offences charged; s.211 requires s.195 CrPC if in relation to court proceeding.

statutes_cited.name: Code of Criminal Procedure, 1898
statutes_cited.relevance: Cognizance barred u/s 195(1)(b) for s.211 IPC if in/relation to court proceeding; scheme of investigation.

outcome.summary: Appeal dismissed; held that cognizance of respondent's complaint valid as no court proceeding existed on date of cognizance, only police investigation; s.195(1)(b) CrPC not applicable; proceedings against appellant to continue.

key_quotes.text: "the point of time at which the legality of the cognizance taken has to be judged is the time when cognizance is actually taken under S. 190, Cr. P.C."
key_quotes.speaker: court

key_quotes.text: "Police investigation is not a proceeding in any Court."
key_quotes.speaker: court

key_quotes.text: "A proceeding in contemplation cannot be said to be a proceeding in a Court."
key_quotes.speaker: court
